Question: How can my students view feedback for each individual question?

1. Student enters the 'My Grades' tool and clicks the title of the test to view the attempt details. If they were to click the blue buBlackboardle next to the score, they will only see the overall feedback.

Question: What do I do if I am unable to view my instructor's lecture on Sharestream?
Answer:
For trouble shooting follow these steps in order:
1. Try accessing the videos directly from within the units
2. Make sure your're not in a private session ( private browsing, incognito mode etc.) and that cookies are enabled for your browser
3. Clear your browsers cache
4. Change your browser ( Google Chrome is recommended) If you are using Google Chrome, make sure it is up-to-date and if so, please try accessing the videos with Mozilla Firefox

Question: Why am I unable to upload content to my course? I see the error message: 'Failed File system entry not readable: /courses/comm2-con'

This problem has been observed in older work-sites. This is due to the fact that Content System permissions were retroactively added. To correct the permissions, do the following:
- Navigate to "COURSEmongo_id > Content System > COURSEmongo_id"
- Click the drop down arrow next to 'Course Content: COURSEmongo_id' > Permissions
- Select Specific Users
- Enter user's netid in the relevant field
- Select 'Read, Write, Remove, Manage'
- Submit change

Question: Why do I see a blank page when I access my course site?
Answer:
There are two possibilities of this issue either1) when there is no content under a course menu ( e.g., Announcement) , or 2) when course materials are stored under course tools in which are only visible to the instructors.

If it is the first case, add the content under the course menu. Then, your students will be able to view the content.

If it is the second case, the course materials have to be moved to the content area in which is visible to students. To move the content materials, please contact us at 312-996-9824. We will walk you through the steps over the phone.

Question: Why am I still seeing the course I dropped?

Question: How can an instructor access their course as a student?
Answer:
Using Student Preview mode allows you to view course site as a student's view, take tests, submit assignments and view your grades.

To enter Student Preview, please follow the steps below.

To view the course as a student,

- Log in to your course site.
- Make sure that the Edit Mode is on at the top right of the course site.
- In the left side of Edit mode, click Student Preview button ( circle arrows) .
- You will be able to view the course content as a student.
- Check "Delete the preview user and all data
- Click Continue.

To take tests or submit assignments

- Follow the steps above
- When exiting Student Preview, click "Keep the preview user and all data."
- Click Continue.
- Your preview user account is created and you now will be able to take tests or submit assignments.

Question: How do I copy content from one course to another?
Answer:
1) Enroll as instructor in destination course
2) Access the Blackboard course you want to copy.
3) On the Control Panel, expand the Packages and Utilities section > Course Copy.
4) Select the option: Copy Course Materials into an Existing Course
5) Click the Browse button to view a list of your courses. In the popup window that appears, select the appropriate course ID from your list of courses and click Submit. The course ID will populate in the Destination Course ID Box.
6) Select the course materials that you want to copy over to the existing course. We recommend Select All.( Unless exceptions are specified)
7) In the File Attachments section, select Copy links and copies of the content. ( if there is .swf select Copy links and copies of the content ( include entire course home folder) )
8) Click Submit.

Note: DO NOT select Include Enrollments in the Copy.

5) In the second course, follow the same path to navigate to the Test manager.
7) Click the Import Test button and find the file on your computer.

Question: Does Blackboard send announcements out without the course being available to students?

Announcements are not visible to students as long as the course is not open to them ( since the said course is not part of their course list) . So the announcement that went out will not be seen by students.

However, if you selected the check-box next to "Email Announcement" the announcement is sent to their UIC email address irrespective of the availability of the course.

Question: Why is Blackboard asking me to install or update my Flash player when I try to play iSpring files, even though I have the latest version on my computer?

Question: How do I download discussion board posts in PDF format?

3. The list of Discussion Forums will open, browse to the forum in question
4. Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Edit Paging" and enter maximum value of entries, and click Go

Question: What is the size limit for files uploaded into SafeAssign and Blackboard assignment space?
Answer:
Upload limit for SafeAssign is 10MB ( text only - PDF, Word) i.e. videos cannot be uploaded to SafeAssign sections.

For Blackboard assignments the upload is limited to 1GB enforced by a hard browser and webserver limit. What this means is with a stable internet connection 1GB of data can be uploaded to the assignment space. Large files take time to upload and it could happen that the session times out, which leaves the action incomplete.

Question: How do I let a student re-submit an assignment?
Answer:
First - clear the first attempt, if applicable. To do that, go Grade Center> click the chevron drop down list next to the student's score > View Grade Details. On this page you have a button to clear attempt.
Next, locate the assignment, select 'edit' with the chevron drop down menu, go to 'Availability' and make it available until the time agreed upon with student & instructor.
Note: If the assignment is still set to allow a 'single attempt', students who submitted will not be able to resubmit. Unfortunately we could not find a way to make the test only available to the individual student, though that is possible with tests.

Question: Why is there extra text/weird formatting when I send an Announcement although it looks fine before sending?
Answer:
If the instructor copied and pasted from Word, that is a known error that sometimes a lot of extra text can end up in the Announcement, even though it looks normal to you before sending.

We are working to integrate Word into BlackBoard but for now, there are a a few workarounds.

First option: Instead of using MS Word, try using a basic text editing program such as Notepad ( for PC) , or Textedit ( for Mac) .

Second option: After copying and pasting the text from MS Word into your new announcement, you can click "remove formatting" from the expanded tool bar menu, just above the spell check button. I included a screenshot of the "remove formatting" button for your reference.

Both of these options should resolve the issue.

See my attached video titled "Adding Tool Links for Portfolios" that I made in a demo site, guiding you through the process.

If you do not add the two links ( or just the general Tools link, which is a link to all tools in BlackBoard) , students will not be able to access it at all. So that is the first step.
More info about adding tool links can also be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=el6fMDAP86w&ab_channel=ACCCInstructionalTechnologyLab

Question: How do I view corrupted documents submitted through blackboard?
Answer:
Any machine with a valid Microsoft Office installation should be able to open a .doc file as it was the standard used by Microsoft Word until 2003 ( unless the version of Word being used predates 2003) . The new default format is .docx so that should work too.

Unfortunately, there are many 'corrupt-my-file' programs available online that will corrupt any file that are passed through their system. In such a case, there is no way to tell if the file was actually corrupted ( rare, but possible) or, corrupted with malicious intent. If this seems like a delay-tactic, you may want to ask your students to submit a PDF file too - it is almost impossible for both files to be corrupted. In this instance, professors may also add the message: "students are responsible for uploading a readable non corrupt word document" to future assignments.

Question: Can students run their own Collaborate sessions?
Answer:
YES, You can allow students to run a session without the presence of an instructor by selecting the option "All users join as moderators" under "Roles and Access" when creating the room. However, students cannot create sessions, so you will have to create the initial session. However, to avoid your having to create a new session every time the student groups want to meet, you can set the "End Date" for the session as the end of the semester. Students will still be able to record their sessions every time they log in, and recordings will be published shortly after all users leave the current session. Marking the "End Date" as the end of the semester ( ex. Dec 10, 2015) should allow students to keep using that room for all of their group sessions. Tips: I would recommend that you create a session for each of your groups, ( ex. Group 1, Group 2) . The students can then join the room corresponding to their assigned group number. Note: All students will be able to join ANY room. If you would like to restrict access to just the students in a specific group, you can do this when you create the session under the "Roles and Access" options.

Question: Why are my iSpring files not working?
Answer:
If your iSpring files are not working, it may be because the iSpring files were not initially packaged correctly. If the method you first used to upload your iSpring files in its original Blackboard course site was to upload your iSpring files into the site's content system and then add the 'index.html' file to your content area from there, you may have trouble with the files in a copied course. This method works for the original course site, as all of the iSpring files are uploaded into that site's content system, but if the site is copied into a future site - the 'index.html' file in the future ( copied) courses would no longer work as all the iSpring files have not been uploaded to the content system, only the 'index.html' file. To fix this, you can follow these steps:
1. Go to one of the original PowerPoint files, click the iSpring tab
2. Click "Publish"
3. In the dialog box that appears, ensure that under "Output Options," both 'Desktop ( Flash) ' and 'All in one Flash file' are selected
4. Click Publish. The progress bar that appears should note that your files, including audio, are being processed
5. The final file will appear in Presentation Preview, so you may view the file and confirm that all is as expected
6. Click "Open Folder" inside Presentation Preview. This will send you to the location of the files inside your computer
7. The only file you will need for Blackboard is the .swf ( Shockwave Flash Object) file. The others ( index and data) can be kept for your records
8. In Blackboard, go to your course and desired content area. Go to Build Content > File and then browse your computer for this newly created .swf file
9. Click Submit
This will upload your iSpring presentations so that they will still be usable when copied to future Blackboard course sites. Please note that, using this method, the presentations will not be playable on iPads - they're best viewed on desktop computers and laptops.

2. On the Tests, Surveys and Pools page, click Tests. The Tests page displays all existing tests, and you can also build new tests here.
3. Select Build Test from the dark grey bar
4. Input the following basic information: name of the test, description, instructions. You can use the content editor functions to format the text and include files, images, web links, multimedia and mashups.
5. Click Submit

After you create a test, you can edit it by:
1. On the Control Panel, expand the Course Tools section and click Tests, Surveys and Pools
2. On the Tests, Surveys and Pools page, click Tests. The Tests page displays all existing tests, here you can select the test you would like to edit.
3. Click on the chevron next to the test you would like to edit, and select edit.

Question: Are instructors able to use letter grades in Blackboard's Grade Center?
Answer:
In order to use letter grades in Blackboard, you must create a 'Grading Schema.' Grading Schema's calculate a percentage based on students' scores versus the number of points possible. From there, you can create a customized Grading Schema for letter grades, pass/fail or other customized grades. To create a grading schema for your course:
1. In the Grade Center, point to Manage on the action bar and click Grading Schemas
2. On the Grading Schemas page, click Create Grading Schema on the action bar
3. Type a Name. The name appears on the Grading Schemas page and in the drop-down lists for primary disply and secondary display when creating or editing columns in the Grade Center.
4. In the Schema Mapping section, two default rows appear with ranges of percentages. You can edit the two ranges to customize a Pass/Fail schema.

Question: How and when can an Instructor remove a question from a test that has already been deployed?

Question: What are I spring files, how do you copy them and how do give permissions to students to view them ?
Answer:
Follow the steps below to create all-in-one iSpring files and upload them:
1. Go to PowerPoint files, click the iSpring tab
2. Click "Publish"
3. In the dialog box that appears, ensure that under "Output Options," both 'Desktop ( Flash) ' and 'All in one Flash file' are selected
4. Click Publish. The progress bar that appears should note that your files, including audio, are being processed
5. The final file will appear in Presentation Preview, so you may view the file and confirm that all is as expected
6. Click "Open Folder" inside Presentation Preview. This will send you to the location of the files inside your computer
7. The only file you will need for Blackboard is the .swf ( Shockwave Flash Object) file. The others ( index and data) can be kept for your records
8. In Blackboard, go to your course and desired content area. Go to Build Content > File and then browse your computer for this newly created .swf file
9. Click Submit

For more details: https://helpdesk.uic.edu/accc/Ticket/Attachment/13067164/7227848/Ispring%20File%20Upload.pdf

For more on giving student permissions to content:
https://blackboardhelp.usc.edu/course-content/content-collection/content-collection-file-permissions/
